newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rupee rallies after dlr demand peters out.
newsitem.headline: Indian rupee rallies after dlr demand peters out.

text.p: The Indian rupee rallied to close firmer against the dollar at 35.920/925 on Friday after weakening to an intra-day low of 35.985, dealers said.
Spot dollar opened steady at 35.945/965 on Friday.
The rupee edged up to the 35.94/95 level in early trade on speculative dollar selling by Bombay banks, dealers said.
Late in the morning session, dollar demand from eastern India emerged, pulling down the rupee to 35.97/98 level.
"There were some dollar buyers at 35.9850 today," said a dealer.
Plentiful dollar selling at this level combined with retreating dollar demand helped push up the rupee to 35.920/925 by the close, firming from 35.94/96 on Thursday.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) continued to be active in the swap segment, buying spot September dollars and dragging down forward premia, dealers said.
The six month forward dollar premium closed the day at 6.79 percent compared with the previous close of 7.01 percent.
Dealers said the RBI would have bought over $700 million in recent weeks through its purchases in the spot and swap markets.
They said the RBI was shoring up its dollar reserves ahead of Saturday's redemption of India Development Bonds which is expected to result in an outflow of about $1.0 billion.
Many dealers expect spot dollar to stabilise around 35.90 next week. "We could see more depreciation coinciding with the budget (scheduled for the month-end)," a dealer said.
A dealer at a French bank in Bombay said the rupee was crying out for a sharper correction in the light of dollar's recent gains against leading global currencies.
"Indian exporters have to compete in a sluggish international market at an exchange rate dating back to 1994/95 level," the bank said in a foreign exchange commentary.
